Idiom (Manx): Cha nel oo ny share er dty ghlioon hene.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: You’re no better than anyone else; a humbling reminder of equality.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Manx saying reflecting community humility and fairness.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Manx): /xa nɛl u nə ʃar ɛr də ɣlʲuːn hɛnə/
First Example Sentence: Cha nel eh ny share er e ghlioon hene, myr t’eh credjal.
Second Example Sentence: Cha nel shin ny share er nyn glioonyn hene, dy jarroo.
Third Example Sentence: Cha nel oo ny share er dty ghlioon hene, as cur moylley ort hene cha jean eh vegg.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: A common Celtic expression used in Manx to inspire courage.
First Example Sentence: Gow greim jeh dty chree, my ven, as jean myr share.
Second Example Sentence: Va mee aggleagh, agh hug mee greim jeem’s jeh my chree.
Third Example Sentence: Gow greim jeh dty chree roish myr ta’n jurnaa toshiaght.

Idiom (Manx): Vel oo goaill yn chione jeh'n raad?
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Interrogative clause with idiomatic object noun phrase.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Do you know what’s going on? Are you paying attention?
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common Manx phrase implying awareness or attention to detail.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Manx): /vɛl u ɡoːl ən xoːnʲ dʒən raːd/
First Example Sentence: Vel oo goaill yn chione jeh’n raad ny smoo na mish?
Second Example Sentence: Cha nel eh goaill yn chione jeh’n raad er chor erbee!
Third Example Sentence: Vel shiu goaill yn chione jeh’n raad, my ghraihyn?

Idiom (Manx): Ta mee er my skyn, myr eiraght.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from older idioms related to physical work and fatigue.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Manx): /ta mi ər mə ʃkɪn mər erəxt/
First Example Sentence: Ta mee er my skyn lesh yn obbyr shoh.
Second Example Sentence: Ta shin er nyn skyn, agh ta'n kianglagh goll er dy mie.
Third Example Sentence: Ta mee er my skyn myr eiraght myr share nagh ren mee cadley.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common in Manx households; literally 'He’s filling my head'.
First Example Sentence: T’eh cooilleeney my chione gys jerrey ny laa.
Second Example Sentence: Va’n paitçhey beg cooilleeney my chione lesh e vraar.
Third Example Sentence: Cha nel mee briaght; t’eh dy jarroo cooilleeney my chione!

Idiom (Manx): Dy row slaynt as seihll dhyt.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Wishing someone health and long life.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: I wish you health and a good life.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Manx blessing; widely used in greetings and ceremonies.
First Example Sentence: Dy row slaynt as seihll dhyt, my charrey.
Second Example Sentence: Dy row slaynt as seihll diu dy bragh.
Third Example Sentence: Dy row slaynt as seihll dhyt ec yn çhiamble.

Idiom (Manx): Ta mee myr fishigey as er jeet dy ve marroo.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Manx maritime metaphor referencing dead fish after fishing trips.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Manx): /ta mi mər fɪʃɪɡə əs ər dʒit də ve maruː/
First Example Sentence: Ta mee myr fishigey as er jeet dy ve marroo lurg yn laa mooar.
Second Example Sentence: Myr fishigey marroo, cha noddym goll magh ny sodjey.
Third Example Sentence: Ta mee myr fishigey as er jeet dy ve marroo, agh ta mee foast bio beg.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Manx phrasing still used widely in instruction and advice.
First Example Sentence: Cur my ner er ny reddyn beggey.
Second Example Sentence: Cur my ner er cre ta’n mainshter gra.
Third Example Sentence: Cur my ner er, as bee oo toiggal ny smoo.

Idiom (Manx): Cha nel eh er e hon hene.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Old Manx idiom used to describe emotional imbalance or illness.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Manx): /xa nɛl ɛ ər ə hon hɛnə/
First Example Sentence: Cha nel eh er e hon hene er y traa shoh.
Second Example Sentence: Ta shin fakin eh, agh cha nel eh er e hon hene.
Third Example Sentence: Cha nel eh er e hon hene er y laa roie.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Declarative clause; coordination of abstract nouns.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Peace and love make people happy.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional poetic expression in Manx verse and blessing culture.
First Example Sentence: Shee as graih bee maynrey ayns nyn greeaghyn.
Second Example Sentence: Shee as graih bee maynrey, as shoh my phadjer.
Third Example Sentence: Shee as graih bee maynrey er y thalloo shoh.
